Title: "Deploying and Managing Azure AI Search with Bicep"
Text:
C:\Users\adamh\Downloads\azure-search.pdf')@allowed([  'default'  'highDensity'])param hostingMode string = 'default'@description('Location for all resources.')param location string = resourceGroup().locationresource search 'Microsoft.Search/searchServices@2020-08-01' = {  name: name  location: location  sku: {    name: sku  }  properties: {The Azure resource defined in this Bicep file:Microsoft.
Search/searchServices: create an Azure AI Search service1. Save the Bicep file as main.bicep to your local computer.2. Deploy the Bicep file using either Azure CLI or Azure PowerShell.Azure CLIWhen the deployment finishes, you should see a message indicating thedeployment succeeded.
Use the Azure portal, Azure CLI, or Azure PowerShell to list the deployed resources inthe resource group.    replicaCount: replicaCount    partitionCount: partitionCount    hostingMode: hostingMode  }}Deploy the Bicep fileCLIaz group create --name exampleRG --location eastusaz deployment group create --resource-group exampleRG --template-file main.
bicep --parameters serviceName=<service-name>７ NoteReplace <service-name> with the name of the Search service. The servicename must only contain lowercase letters, digits, or dashes. You can't use adash as the first two characters or the last character. The name has aminimum length of 2 characters and a maximum length of 60 characters. Review deployed resourcesCLIAzure CLIOther Azure AI Search quickstarts and tutorials build upon this quickstart. If you plan tocontinue on to work with subsequent quickstarts and tutorials, you may wish to leavethis resource in place. When no longer needed, use the Azure portal, Azure CLI, or AzurePowerShell to delete the resource group and its resources.
